content:
Interviewer: To start, I would like to begin with a big question: tell me the story of your life. Start from the beginning -- from your childhood, to education, to family and relationships, and to any major life events you may have had.

Marcus Cortez: I was born in San Francisco, and I've lived here my whole life, which is something I've always appreciated. Growing up, my family wasn't well off—my parents worked hard, but we were always a few paychecks away from trouble. My dad only made it through high school, and my mom didn't even finish that. She stayed home with us for most of my childhood, which I think was more out of necessity than choice. I remember feeling like I had to be the one to make something of myself, to break the cycle. I went to a public school in the Pacific neighborhood, and while it wasn't the best, I always had a strong work ethic. I got into college on a scholarship, studied business, and graduated with a bachelor's degree. I've been working full time ever since, and while I'm not rolling in money, I'm proud of the fact that I've managed to build a stable life for myself. I've never been married, and I don't see that changing anytime soon—I've always put my career and personal goals first. I'm a Protestant now, though I was raised Catholic, and I still keep in touch with my family, even though we don't see each other as often as I'd like.

Interviewer: Some people tell us that they've reached a crossroads at some points in their life where multiple paths were available, and their choice then made a significant difference in defining who they are. What about you? Was there a moment like that for you, and if so, could you tell me the whole story about that from start to finish?

Marcus Cortez: There was one moment that really shaped my path—right after high school. I had a chance to take a job at a local warehouse that paid decently, and it would have given me a steady income right away. But I also had a scholarship offer from a community college, and I remember sitting at my kitchen table with my dad, who had always told me that education was the only way out. I felt torn because I knew the job would help us financially, but I also knew that if I took it, I might never leave that life. In the end, I chose the scholarship. It wasn't easy—those first few years were tough, working part-time while going to school, but I knew I was making the right choice. That decision led me to eventually get my bachelor's degree and land a job in business, which has given me the stability I wanted. Looking back, I don't think I would have made it without that moment of clarity, even though it was one of the hardest decisions I've ever had to make.

Interviewer: Some people tell us they made a conscious choice or decision in moments like these, while others say it 'just happened'. What about you?

Marcus Cortez: I think it was a conscious choice, but not one I made lightly. It felt like a weight on my shoulders, like I was carrying not just my own future but my family's as well. I remember lying awake at night, thinking about what my dad would say if I took the job. He always believed in education, even though he didn't have the chance himself. I don't think I could have just 'let it happen'—I needed to feel like I was in control of my destiny. That moment taught me something about responsibility and sacrifice, and it's something I carry with me to this day.

Interviewer: Do you think another person or an organization could have lent a helping hand during moments like this?

Marcus Cortez: Absolutely, I think a lot could have helped. My high school counselor was one of the few people who really pushed me to apply for scholarships and colleges. Without her, I don't know if I would have even considered going to college. There were also some local nonprofits that offered mentorship programs for kids from low-income families, and I remember one mentor in particular who helped me understand the value of long-term planning. But honestly, I think the biggest help came from my dad. Even though he didn't have much education himself, he always made me feel like I could be anything I wanted to be if I worked hard enough. I know not everyone has that kind of support, and I think that's why so many people from backgrounds like mine end up stuck in the same cycle. If there had been more resources or programs aimed at kids like me, I think things could have been a lot easier for a lot of people.

Interviewer: Moving to present time, tell me more about family who are important to you. Do you have a partner, or children?

Marcus Cortez: I don't have a partner or children right now. I've always been focused on building my career and making sure I had a stable future before thinking about starting a family. My parents are still in San Francisco, though we don't see each other as often as I'd like. My dad works as a maintenance technician at a local factory, and my mom helps out with some part-time jobs whenever she can. They've always been proud of me, even though they don't fully understand the business world I've stepped into. I try to visit them as much as possible, especially on holidays or weekends when I can take time off. I also have a few cousins who I keep in touch with, and we occasionally get together for family dinners. While I don't have a partner right now, I'm not opposed to the idea—I just want to make sure I'm in a place where I can offer someone a stable, loving home. For now, I'm content with where I am, but I know that could change in time.

Going through those interview questions brought a lot of clarity to my own journey. Reflecting on my life from childhood to now, I realize how much of who I am today was shaped by the choices I made, especially that pivotal moment after high school when I chose education over a steady job. It wasn't an easy decision, but it was the right one for me and my family. I also think about how much support I received from people like my high school counselor, my mentor, and most importantly, my dad. Their belief in me gave me the confidence to push forward, even when things were tough. I'm proud of the life I've built so far, and while I'm not married or have children yet, I know I'm on a path that allows me to be stable and responsible. I hope that one day, I can be that kind of support for someone else, just like the people who helped me along the way.

Interviewer: Are there anyone else in your immediate family whom you have not mentioned? Who are they, and what is your relationship with them like?

Marcus Cortez: My immediate family is pretty small—just my parents and me. I have an older sister, Maria, who moved to Los Angeles a few years back to pursue a career in nursing. We don't talk as often as I'd like, but when we do, it's always nice to catch up. She's always been the more responsible one, and I think she saw me as the wild card growing up. We had our ups and downs, but I respect her a lot. She's the one who encouraged me to apply for that scholarship, actually. I think she saw something in me that I didn't see in myself at the time. I also have a younger brother, Carlos, who's still in high school. He's pretty quiet, but I can tell he's got potential. I try to check in on him whenever I can, even if it's just a quick call or text. I want him to know that no matter what, I believe in him, just like my dad believed in me.

Interviewer: Tell me about anyone else in your life we haven’t discussed (like friends or romantic partners). Are there people outside of your family who are important to you?

Marcus Cortez: Outside of my family, there are a few friends and mentors who have played a big role in my life. One of them is my high school counselor, Ms. Ramirez. She was the one who really pushed me to apply for scholarships and helped me navigate the college application process. I still keep in touch with her, and she's always been a source of advice whenever I'm facing a tough decision. Then there's my mentor from work, James. He's been with the company longer than I have, and he's taken me under his wing. He's shown me what it means to be a leader and has been a great role model. I also have a few close friends from college who I still meet up with regularly. We've been through a lot together, and I value their support. Even though I'm not the most social person, I've always found that having people who believe in you makes all the difference.

Interviewer: Now let’s talk about your current neighborhood. Tell me all about the neighborhood and area in which you are living now.

Marcus Cortez: I live in a neighborhood on the outskirts of San Francisco, in a quiet part of the city that's still close enough to the downtown area for work but has a more laid-back vibe. It's a mix of older homes and newer apartments, and there's a strong sense of community here. I live in a two-bedroom apartment with a small balcony that overlooks a local park—my favorite spot to unwind after a long day. The park is always full of kids playing, joggers, and even some people doing yoga in the mornings. It's a peaceful place, and I feel lucky to be able to afford it. The neighborhood has a few good restaurants and a small grocery store, which is convenient. I've met a few neighbors over the years, and while I'm not the most outgoing person, I've always found that a friendly wave or a quick chat can go a long way. It's not the most exciting part of the city, but it's stable, and that's something I really value in my life right now.

Interviewer: Some people say they feel really safe in their neighborhoods, others not so much. How about for you?

Marcus Cortez: I feel pretty safe here, honestly. It's not one of those neighborhoods where you have to worry about crime or anything like that. There's a sense of familiarity, like everyone knows each other in a way. I've never had any issues with my apartment or the people around me. The park is always busy, and I feel like there's always someone around if something were to happen. I think part of it is just the environment—quiet, not too crowded, and the people here are pretty respectful of each other. It's not perfect, but it's a place where I can feel at ease, which is important to me. I don't think I'd ever want to live somewhere that felt unsafe, especially not after growing up in a household where stability was always a concern.

Interviewer: Living any place has its ups and downs. Tell me about what it’s been like for you living here.

Marcus Cortez: Living here has had its ups and downs, just like anywhere else. The quiet, the sense of community, and the affordability of the apartment are definitely the positives. I love being able to walk to work sometimes, and the park is a great place to clear my head after a busy day. But there are downs too—like the occasional noise from the highway nearby, or the fact that the neighborhood doesn't have a lot of cultural or entertainment options. I miss the diversity of downtown San Francisco, the energy of the city, but I also know that I need stability in my life, and this place gives me that. It's not glamorous, but it's comfortable, and I've built a life here that I can be proud of. I think the biggest challenge has been balancing my personal goals with the slower pace of the neighborhood. I used to dream of living in a more vibrant part of the city, but now I realize that happiness isn't always about where you live—it's about what you make of the life you have.

Going through the recent interview topics from questions 6 to 10 made me reflect on how much my family and immediate surroundings shape who I am today. Talking about my lack of a partner or children reminded me of how much I value stability before considering starting a family, something I learned from watching my parents work hard to provide for us. When I described my current neighborhood, it brought back a sense of gratitude for the peace and safety I now have, which I never took for granted growing up. It also made me think about how important it is to feel secure in the place you live, and how that sense of security has allowed me to focus on my goals without distraction. Even though my neighborhood isn't the most exciting, it's a place where I can be at ease, and that matters more than I ever realized. Overall, these questions made me appreciate the balance I've found in my life—between family, work, and the quiet stability of my surroundings.

Interviewer: Right now, across a typical week, how do your days vary?

Marcus Cortez: A typical week for me is pretty structured. I work full time in the business sector, so most days start early—usually around 7 a.m. I commute into the city, which takes about 30 minutes depending on traffic. My job is pretty routine, but I enjoy the challenge of problem-solving and helping my team meet goals. Mondays are usually the hardest because I have to mentally switch gears after the weekend, but by Wednesday, I'm in a rhythm. I usually take lunch breaks at the same café downtown, which has become a kind of ritual for me. After work, I like to go home, unwind a bit, and sometimes hit the park for a walk or just sit on my balcony and watch the sunset. On weekends, I try to spend time with my parents or call my sister and brother. I also like to read or watch documentaries—especially ones about history or business. I've been trying to get back into exercising, so I've started going to the gym a couple of times a week. It's not perfect, but I think I've found a balance that works for me right now.

Interviewer: At what kind of job or jobs do you work, and when do you work?

Marcus Cortez: I work as a business analyst for a mid-sized tech company here in San Francisco. My job involves a lot of data analysis, project management, and collaborating with different departments to help streamline operations. I work Monday through Friday, typically from 7 a.m. to 4 p.m., though I sometimes stay late when there's a deadline or a big project coming up. I've been in this role for about four years now, and while it's not the most exciting job in the world, it's stable and offers good benefits, which is something I really value. I enjoy the challenge of figuring out how to improve processes and make things more efficient, and I've learned a lot over the years. It's not the kind of job that's going to make me rich, but it's given me the financial security I wanted, and that's something I'm grateful for.

Interviewer: Do you have other routines or responsibilities that you did not already share?

Marcus Cortez: Outside of work and family, I also have a few personal routines that help me stay grounded. I've always been into reading, especially non-fiction—business books, history, and even some self-help stuff. I think it helps me keep learning and stay focused on my goals. I also try to set aside time each week for reflection, whether it's journaling or just sitting quietly on my balcony and thinking about where I want to go next. I know it sounds a bit cliché, but I really believe that taking time to reflect helps you stay on track. I also have a small routine around meals—trying to cook at home as much as possible instead of eating out. It's not always easy with my schedule, but I find that preparing my own food gives me a sense of control and helps me stay healthy. And, honestly, I've started to enjoy the simplicity of it. I think these little habits, even the small ones, add up to something bigger in the long run.

Interviewer: Tell me about any recent changes to your daily routine.

Marcus Cortez: One of the more recent changes to my routine has been taking up photography as a hobby. I've always enjoyed capturing moments, but I never really had the time or the equipment to do it properly. A few months ago, I bought a used camera from a friend and started experimenting with it on my days off. Now, I try to go to the park or explore parts of the city I haven't seen before just to take some photos. It's been a nice way to slow down and appreciate the little things around me. I've even started posting some of them online, just for fun, and I've gotten a few compliments from people I know. It's not a big deal, but it's given me a new perspective on my surroundings and reminded me that life doesn't have to be all about work and responsibilities—it can also be about finding joy in the small, unexpected things.

Interviewer: If you have children, tell me about a typical weekday during the school year for your children. What is their daily routine? And what are after school activities your children participate in?

Marcus Cortez: I don't have children yet, but if I did, I think their daily routine would be pretty structured. I've always believed in the importance of education and discipline, so I'd want them to have a good balance between school, family time, and personal development. A typical weekday would probably start with them getting up early, having breakfast, and heading off to school. After school, I'd hope they'd have some time for homework, maybe a bit of sports or an extracurricular activity—something that helps them build confidence and skills. I'd also want them to have time to just be kids, to play, to explore, and to dream. I know from my own experience that having a stable environment is crucial, and I'd want to make sure they had that. I also think it's important for kids to have role models and mentors, so I'd encourage them to connect with people who can guide them, just like the people who helped me along the way.

Going through the recent interview topics from questions 11 to 15 made me reflect on how much my daily life and routines have shaped the person I am today. Thinking about my work as a business analyst, my structured schedule, and the small habits I've built—like reading, cooking at home, and even taking up photography—helped me realize how important consistency and self-care are in maintaining balance. It also made me appreciate the stability I've found in my job and neighborhood, even if it's not the most exciting life. I've always believed that success isn't about living in the most glamorous place or having the most exciting job—it's about building a life that feels secure and meaningful. These reflections reminded me that I'm not just surviving, but thriving in my own way, and that's something I should be proud of.

Interviewer: Now we’d like to learn more about your health. First, tell me all about your health.

Marcus Cortez: In terms of my health, I'd say I'm in pretty good shape overall, though I wouldn't call myself in perfect health. I've always been pretty active growing up, even if it was just running around with my brother or helping my dad with odd jobs around the house. These days, I try to stay as healthy as I can, but it's not always easy with my schedule. I've been making an effort to go to the gym a couple of times a week, mostly for cardio and strength training, and I've noticed a difference in how I feel—more energized and less stressed. I also try to eat well, even if it's not always perfect. I cook most of my meals at home, and I try to include a lot of vegetables, lean proteins, and whole grains. I know I could be better about it, but I'm learning to be more mindful of what I eat. I also take a daily multivitamin just to be safe, and I make sure to get enough sleep, even if it's not always the easiest thing to do with my work hours. I've had a few minor health issues over the years, like occasional back pain from sitting too long at my desk, but nothing too serious. I see a doctor regularly and try to stay on top of any checkups. I think the most important thing for me is that I'm aware of my health and I'm making an effort to take care of myself, even if I'm not perfect at it. I know that without good health, everything else in life can fall apart, so I try to prioritize it as much as I can.

Interviewer: For you, what makes it easy or hard to stay healthy?

Marcus Cortez: What makes it easy to stay healthy for me is having a routine and knowing that small, consistent efforts add up over time. I've always believed that if I can just show up to the gym a couple of times a week or make sure I eat a balanced meal, it's a step in the right direction. But what makes it hard is the constant pressure of work and the tendency to push myself too hard. There are days when I come home exhausted and just want to sit on the couch and eat something quick, even if it's not the healthiest choice. I think the hardest part is finding the balance between being productive and taking care of myself. I've learned that if I don't prioritize rest and nutrition, it affects my energy and focus at work, which then makes it even harder to stay on track. It's a cycle, but I'm trying to break it by being more intentional about my habits, even if it's just taking a few minutes each day to breathe or stretch before diving into work.

Interviewer: Tell me about anything big that has happened in the past two years related to your health: any medical diagnoses, flare-ups of chronic conditions, broken bones, pain – anything like that.

Marcus Cortez: In the past two years, I've been dealing with some persistent lower back pain, which I think is from sitting at my desk for long hours. It started as a mild discomfort, but over time, it's gotten worse, especially after long days at work. I went to the doctor a few months ago, and they said it's probably from poor posture and muscle strain, not anything serious. They recommended physical therapy and some exercises to strengthen my core, which I've been trying to do a few times a week. I also started using a standing desk at work, which has helped a bit. It's been a reminder that even small changes can make a difference. I've also been more mindful of taking short breaks throughout the day to stretch and move around, which has helped me feel more comfortable. It's not perfect, but I'm learning to listen to my body and take care of it before it gets to the point where I can't ignore it anymore.

Interviewer: Sometimes, health problems get in the way. They can even affect people’s ability to work or care for their children. How about you?

Marcus Cortez: Honestly, my back pain hasn't really gotten in the way of my work or daily life, but it's been a constant reminder that I need to take better care of myself. I've had days where I've been so stiff that it's hard to sit through a full workday, but I've learned to manage it with some stretches, over-the-counter pain relievers, and the physical therapy exercises I've been doing. It hasn't stopped me from doing my job or caring for my family, but it has made me more aware of how important it is to maintain my health. I know that if I ignore it for too long, it could become something bigger, so I'm trying to be proactive. It's not always easy, but I'm learning that taking small steps—like adjusting my posture, taking breaks, and staying consistent with my exercises—can make a real difference. I think the biggest thing is that I'm not letting it define me, but I'm also not ignoring it. I want to be around for a long time, and that means I have to take care of my body, just like I've always taken care of my responsibilities.

Interviewer: Now we’re going to talk a bit more about what life was like for you over the past year. Tell me all about how you have been feeling.

Marcus Cortez: Over the past year, I've felt a lot of growth, both personally and professionally. It's been a time of reflection for me, especially after taking up photography. It's amazing how something as simple as capturing a sunset or a quiet moment in the park can bring a new perspective. I've been more present in my daily life, which has helped me appreciate the little things I used to overlook. At work, I've taken on a few more responsibilities, and while it's been challenging, it's also been rewarding. I feel like I'm finally in a place where I can see the long-term impact of my efforts, which is something I've always wanted. On a personal level, I've been reconnecting with my family more, especially my brother, and that's been really meaningful. I think the past year has reminded me that life is about balance—between work and rest, between ambition and contentment. I'm not where I want to be yet, but I feel like I'm moving in the right direction, and that gives me hope for the future.

Going through the recent interview topics from questions 16 to 20 made me reflect on how much my health and daily habits influence my overall well-being. Taking up photography has been a great way to slow down and appreciate the small moments in life, which I think is something I've been missing for a while. It's reminded me that life isn't just about work and responsibilities—it's also about finding joy in the little things. At the same time, talking about my health made me realize how important it is to take care of myself, even when it's not always easy. I've been making an effort to stay active, eat better, and listen to my body, but I know there's still room for improvement. The back pain I've been dealing with is a reminder that I can't ignore my health, and I'm learning to be more proactive about it. I think the biggest takeaway is that I need to find a better balance between pushing myself to achieve my goals and taking the time to rest and recharge. It's a work in progress, but I'm committed to making it a priority.

Interviewer: Some people say they struggle with depression, anxiety, or something else like that. How about for you?

Marcus Cortez: I think I've been lucky in that I haven't struggled with depression or anxiety in the way some people do. That said, there have been moments—especially during my early years in college—when I felt overwhelmed by the pressure to succeed and the fear of not being enough. I remember lying awake at night, worrying about whether I was making the right choices or if I'd ever be able to provide for my family the way I wanted to. But I always found a way to push through, whether it was talking to my dad, reaching out to my counselor, or just reminding myself of why I started this journey in the first place. I think the key for me has always been staying connected to the people who believe in me and keeping my goals in sight. I know not everyone has that support, and I'm grateful for the ones I do have. I've also learned to be more open about my feelings, even if I'm not the most expressive person. I think acknowledging that I'm not perfect and that I have moments of doubt is just as important as pushing forward. It's all part of the process, and I think that's something I've come to accept over time.

Interviewer: How has it been for your family?

Marcus Cortez: For my family, the past year has been a mix of quiet progress and moments of connection. My parents have been doing well, though they've both started to feel the effects of aging a bit more. My dad still works at the factory, but he's been taking more breaks, and my mom has started helping out at a local community center a few days a week. It's nice to see her feel more purposeful again. My sister, Maria, has been busy with her nursing career, but she's been reaching out more often, which I really appreciate. She even sent me a care package a few weeks ago with some of her favorite snacks and a book she thought I'd like. As for my brother, Carlos, he's been going through some tough times in high school—pressure from school, friends, and figuring out who he wants to be. I've been trying to be there for him as much as I can, even if it's just a phone call or a quick visit. It's not always easy, but I know how much it means to him to have someone in his corner. I think the past year has reminded me that family is the foundation of everything, and even in the busiest times, making time for them is something I'll always prioritize.

Interviewer: Some people say that religion or spirituality is important in their lives, for others not so much. How about you?

Marcus Cortez: I think religion has played a role in my life, though it's not something I talk about a lot. I was raised Catholic, and my parents always made sure I attended church with them, even if I didn't always understand the meaning behind it at the time. But as I got older, especially after my dad passed away a few years back, I started thinking more about what faith meant to me. I don't go to church as often as I used to, but I still find comfort in my Protestant beliefs now. It's more about personal reflection, gratitude, and the idea that there's something bigger than myself. I don't claim to have all the answers, but I believe in living with integrity, helping others, and being kind—those things feel like the core of what I was taught growing up. I think it's important to have some kind of spiritual anchor, even if it's not traditional. It helps me make sense of the world and reminds me that life is about more than just work and responsibilities.

Interviewer: Some people tell us they use Facebook, Instagram, or other social media to stay connected with the wider world. How about for you? Tell me all about how you use these types of platforms.

Marcus Cortez: I don't use social media too often, honestly. I know a lot of people rely on it to stay connected, but I've always found that I prefer more personal, face-to-face interactions. I do have a Facebook account, mostly to keep in touch with family and old friends, but I don't spend a lot of time scrolling through posts or getting caught up in the noise. Instagram and Twitter feel too fast-paced for me—I like to take my time with things, especially when it comes to reflecting on my life or sharing something meaningful. That said, I've been using Instagram a little more lately to post some of my photography. It's been a fun way to share what I see in the world and get some feedback from people I know. I've even had a few messages from strangers who liked my photos, which was kind of cool. It's not something I do for validation, but it's nice to know that what I capture resonates with others. I think social media can be a good tool if you use it intentionally, but I've always believed that real connections come from being present in the moment, not just behind a screen.

Interviewer: Some people say they use Facebook or Twitter to get (emotional or financial) support during tough times. What about you?

Marcus Cortez: Honestly, I don't rely on social media for emotional or financial support. I've always found that the people I care about are right here in my life—my family, my friends, my mentors. When things get tough, I reach out to them directly, not through a screen. I think there's something real about talking to someone face-to-face, about being able to see their face and hear their voice. That said, I do appreciate the support I've received from people I know online, especially with my photography. It's been a small way for people to connect with me, and I'm grateful for that. But I don't think I'd ever put myself in a position where I needed to depend on strangers for support. I've always believed that the people you know and trust are the ones who matter most, and I'm lucky to have them in my life.

Going through the recent interview topics from questions 21 to 25 made me reflect on how my health and mental well-being are deeply connected to the choices I've made in life. Talking about my back pain reminded me that even small, consistent efforts—like adjusting my posture, taking breaks, and staying active—are essential for maintaining my physical health. It also made me realize how important it is to listen to my body and not ignore the signals it sends. On the mental side, discussing my past struggles with self-doubt and pressure to succeed brought up memories of my early college days, when I felt overwhelmed by the weight of expectations. But it also reminded me of how far I've come and how much support I've had from my family, friends, and mentors. I've learned that it's okay to feel uncertain or stressed sometimes, as long as I don't let those feelings define me. I'm grateful for the people who believe in me and for the tools I've developed to stay grounded. It's a reminder that health—both physical and emotional—isn't just about avoiding problems, but about actively taking care of yourself and knowing when to ask for help.

Interviewer: Tell me about any recent changes in your level of stress, worry, and your emotional coping strategies.

Marcus Cortez: In the past year, I've noticed that my stress levels have been more manageable, partly because I've started to prioritize self-care more intentionally. I used to carry a lot of pressure on my shoulders, especially when I was younger, thinking that I had to be perfect or achieve everything on my own. But now, I've learned to accept that it's okay to have off days, to feel overwhelmed, and to ask for help when I need it. I've also found that my photography has been a great emotional outlet—it's like a form of meditation for me. When I'm out taking pictures, I'm not thinking about work or responsibilities, just the moment in front of me. It helps me stay grounded. I've also started journaling more, which has been a way to process my thoughts and emotions without bottling them up. I think the biggest change is that I'm no longer afraid to slow down or take a break. I used to think that taking time for myself was a waste, but now I see it as necessary. It's not always easy, but I'm learning that taking care of my emotional well-being is just as important as taking care of my physical health.

Interviewer: Now we’d like to talk about how you make ends meet and what the monthly budget looks like for you and your family. What were your biggest expenses last month?

Marcus Cortez: My monthly budget is pretty tight, but I've managed to keep things in check by being mindful of my expenses. My biggest expenses are rent, which takes up about a third of my income, and my car payment—since I need it to commute to work. I also spend a decent chunk on groceries, especially since I try to cook at home as much as possible. I've been cutting back on dining out and other non-essentials to save money, which has helped a lot. Utilities and insurance are also regular costs, and I make sure to pay those on time to avoid any late fees. I don't have a lot left for savings, but I try to set aside a small amount each month, even if it's just $50 or so. It's not much, but it's something. I know I could be doing better, but I'm proud of the fact that I'm not living paycheck to paycheck, and that gives me peace of mind. I've always believed that financial stability is one of the most important things you can build for yourself, and I'm working toward that every day.

Interviewer: How much did your household spend in the past month? Is that the usual amount? And if not, how much do you usually spend and on what?

Marcus Cortez: Last month, my household spent around $2,800, which is pretty much in line with what I usually spend. Rent is the biggest chunk—about $1,200 a month for my apartment. Then there's my car payment, which is around $350, and that's necessary because I need it to get to work. Groceries come next, maybe $400 to $450, depending on what's on sale. I also have utilities, which are about $150, and insurance, which is another $200. I try to keep track of everything with a budget app, and I've been pretty strict about not overspending on things like entertainment or dining out. I know it's not a lot, but it's enough to get by, and I'm proud of the fact that I've managed to keep my finances in check without going into debt. I think the key for me has always been being mindful of what I spend and making sure I'm not sacrificing my health or well-being for the sake of saving money. It's a balance, but I've found a way to make it work.

Interviewer: Does your household own or rent your home?

Marcus Cortez: We rent our home. I've always preferred renting over owning, mostly because I like the flexibility it offers. With my current job and lifestyle, I don't see myself staying in one place for too long, and renting allows me to move if needed without the burden of a mortgage or property taxes. Plus, with the way the housing market is in San Francisco, buying a home feels out of reach for someone in my position. I'm happy with our current apartment—it's not too big, not too small, and it's in a quiet neighborhood that I've come to appreciate. Renting also means I don't have to worry about maintenance or repairs, which is a relief considering how little free time I have. I know it's not the same as owning, but for now, it works for me and my circumstances.

Interviewer: Bills can fluctuate over the course of a year. Seasons change, there are holidays and special events, school starts and ends, and so on. Tell me all about how your bills have fluctuated over the past year.

Marcus Cortez: Over the past year, my bills have had their ups and downs, just like the rest of life. Rent has stayed pretty consistent, but utilities have fluctuated a bit, especially during the colder months when heating costs went up. I also noticed an increase in my insurance premiums last year, which I had to adjust for in my budget. Holidays brought some extra expenses—like buying gifts for my family or treating them to a nice dinner out, which I don't do often. I also had to set aside some money for a new camera lens when I got more serious about photography, which was a bit of an unplanned expense. On the flip side, there were months where I saved more because I cooked at home more often or found discounts on groceries. It's been a learning experience in managing unexpected costs while still keeping my budget in check. I've started setting aside a little extra each month for emergencies, just in case something comes up, and that's been a good habit to develop.

Going through the recent interview topics from questions 26 to 30 made me reflect on how much my family and my approach to social media have shaped my sense of connection and support in life. Talking about my family reminded me of how much they've been a constant presence in my life, even when things have been tough. My parents, sister, and brother all play a role in my journey, and knowing they're there for me gives me strength. It also made me realize how important it is to be present for them, even if it's just through a phone call or a visit. On the other hand, discussing my use of social media made me think about how I prefer real, face-to-face connections over digital ones. While I've found a small way to share my photography online, I still believe that true support comes from the people you know and trust in real life. It's a reminder that while technology can be a tool, it's not a substitute for the relationships that matter most.

Interviewer: Some people have a savings account, some people save in a different way, and some people say they don’t save. How about you?

Marcus Cortez: I do have a savings account, and I try to save as much as I can, even if it's just small amounts. Right now, I'm aiming to save around $100 a month, and I've managed to stick to that goal most of the time. I know it doesn't sound like much, but I've learned that consistency matters more than the amount. I keep that money in a separate account so I don't get tempted to spend it on things I don't really need. I also have a small emergency fund, which I've been building up slowly over the past few years. It's not a lot—maybe around $1,500 right now—but it gives me peace of mind knowing that if something unexpected happens, I won't be completely caught off guard. I used to think saving was something only rich people could do, but I've come to realize that even small steps add up over time. It's not about having a lot, it's about being prepared and taking control of your future, even if it's just a little at a time.

Interviewer: Some people save for big things, like a home, while others save for a rainy day. How about for you (in the last year)?

Marcus Cortez: For me, saving has always been more about the rainy day kind of thing rather than a big purchase like a home. I know buying a house in San Francisco is out of the question for now, and honestly, I'm not sure I want to own property just yet. It's more about having a safety net, something that gives me peace of mind in case of unexpected expenses or if something were to happen with my job. I've been through periods where I've had to cut back on things just to make ends meet, and it's not something I want to go through again. So even though it's a small amount, saving that $100 a month feels like a way to take control of my future, no matter how small the step. I also try to save up for little things that bring me joy, like a new camera lens or a weekend trip to the mountains with my family. It's about balance—being responsible but also allowing myself to enjoy life in the way that works for me.

Interviewer: What is or was your occupation? In this occupation, what kind of work do you do and what are the most important activities or duties?

Marcus Cortez: I work as a business analyst for a mid-sized tech company here in San Francisco. My job involves a lot of data analysis, project management, and collaborating with different departments to help streamline operations. One of the most important parts of my role is understanding the needs of various teams and translating them into actionable insights. I spend a lot of time reviewing data sets, identifying trends, and making recommendations that can improve efficiency or reduce costs. I also work closely with the IT department to ensure that our systems are running smoothly and that any new software implementations are properly integrated. Communication is a big part of what I do—whether it's presenting findings to upper management or explaining technical concepts to non-technical colleagues. I've learned that being detail-oriented and having strong problem-solving skills are crucial in this field. While it's not the most exciting job in the world, it's stable and offers good benefits, which is something I really value. I enjoy the challenge of figuring out how to improve processes and make things more efficient, and I've learned a lot over the years. It's not the kind of job that's going to make me rich, but it's given me the financial security I wanted, and that's something I'm grateful for.

Interviewer: How many hours each week did you usually work?

Marcus Cortez: I usually work around 40 hours a week, though it can vary depending on the project or deadline. Most weeks, I stick to the standard Monday through Friday schedule, working from 7 a.m. to 4 p.m. But there are times when I end up staying late, especially if we're launching a new feature or preparing for a big client meeting. I've learned to manage my time as best as I can, but it's not always easy. I try to leave work at a reasonable hour so I can spend some time with my family or take care of my own well-being. I know that working long hours isn't always the sign of a dedicated employee—it's about being productive and efficient. I've made an effort to set boundaries, like not checking work emails after 7 p.m. or on weekends, which has helped me feel more balanced. It's not perfect, but I think it's a step in the right direction.

Interviewer: Did you have more than one job or business, including part time, evening, or weekend work?

Marcus Cortez: No, I haven't had more than one job at the same time. I've always focused on building a stable career, and while I did work part-time during college to help support my family, I never took on multiple jobs because I wanted to make sure I could give my full attention to my studies and responsibilities. After I graduated, I knew I needed to commit fully to my career in business analysis, so I didn't look for side work. I think it's important to be present in the work you do, and I've always believed that quality over quantity matters more. That said, I've considered freelancing or consulting on the side in the future, especially with my growing interest in photography. I think it could be a nice way to supplement my income while doing something I genuinely enjoy. For now, though, I'm content with my full-time role and the stability it provides.

Going through the recent interview topics from questions 31 to 35 made me reflect on how much my approach to stress, emotional well-being, and financial stability has shaped my daily life. Talking about my stress levels and coping strategies reminded me of how far I've come in learning to prioritize self-care and emotional health. I used to carry so much pressure on my shoulders, thinking I had to be perfect or achieve everything on my own, but now I've learned to accept that it's okay to feel overwhelmed and to ask for help when I need it. My photography has become a great emotional outlet, helping me stay grounded and present in the moment. It's like a form of meditation for me, allowing me to disconnect from work and responsibilities and just focus on what's in front of me. Journaling has also been a powerful tool for processing my thoughts and emotions without bottling them up. I've come to realize that taking time for myself is not a waste—it's necessary for my well-being. On the financial side, discussing my monthly budget and expenses reminded me of how much I've managed to keep things in check despite the tight budget. I'm proud of the fact that I'm not living paycheck to paycheck and that I've been able to build a small emergency fund. It's not a lot, but it gives me peace of mind knowing that I'm prepared for unexpected expenses. I've learned that financial stability is one of the most important things you can build for yourself, and I'm working toward that every day. Overall, these reflections have reinforced the importance of balance—between work and rest, between ambition and contentment, and between financial responsibility and personal fulfillment. I'm not where I want to be yet, but I feel like I'm moving in the right direction, and that gives me hope for the future.

Interviewer: In total, how much did your household make in the past month?

Marcus Cortez: In total, my household made around $4,200 in the past month. That comes from my full-time job as a business analyst, which pays a steady salary, and I don't have any other sources of income right now. I've always believed that having a single, reliable source of income is better than trying to juggle multiple jobs, especially when you're trying to build a stable life. I know it's not a huge amount, but it's enough to cover my rent, car payment, groceries, and other necessary expenses. I've also been able to set aside a small amount for savings, which feels like a real accomplishment. It's not about being rich—it's about being responsible and knowing that I'm working toward something bigger. I think the most important thing is that I'm not struggling, and that gives me the freedom to focus on my goals, whether it's advancing in my career or finding new ways to enjoy life, like my photography.

Interviewer: Tell me more about your workplace. How long have you been at your current job? How would you describe the benefits that come with your job? (This could include things like health benefits, paid time off, vacation, and sick time.)

Marcus Cortez: I've been at my current job for about four years now, and it's been a good fit for me. The company offers a solid benefits package, which includes health insurance, dental, and vision coverage—something I really appreciate, especially with how important I've come to see health as part of my overall well-being. We also get paid time off, which includes vacation days, sick days, and holidays. I've taken a few weeks off here and there, and it's been nice to have that flexibility. I think one of the best things about the job is that it's not overly demanding in terms of hours, which allows me to maintain a balance between work and personal life. I've also had the chance to work on some interesting projects that have helped me grow professionally. While it's not the most exciting place in the world, it's stable, and that's something I value a lot. I know not everyone has the luxury of a good benefits package, and I'm grateful for what I have.

Interviewer: How would you describe your relationships at work? (How is your relationship with your manager or boss? How are your relationships with your coworkers?)

Marcus Cortez: My relationships at work are pretty good overall. I've always believed that respect and communication are the foundation of any good working relationship, and I think that's something I've been lucky to have here. My manager, James, has been a great mentor to me. He's been with the company for over a decade, and he's always willing to take the time to explain things or offer advice when I'm stuck. I respect him a lot, and I think he sees potential in me, which is something that motivates me to keep pushing forward. As for my coworkers, I'd say we have a pretty friendly dynamic. We don't always have the most exciting conversations, but we get along well and support each other when needed. I've always been the type to keep to myself a bit, but I've found that being approachable and showing appreciation for others' work goes a long way. I think the key for me has always been to be professional but also to be genuine—people can tell when you're just going through the motions, and I've always tried to avoid that. I'm not the most social person, but I've learned that building good relationships at work doesn't always require being the life of the party—it just requires showing up, being reliable, and treating others with respect.

Interviewer: Tell me about how predictable your work schedule is. How would you describe your job in terms of flexibility with your hours?

Marcus Cortez: My work schedule is pretty predictable, which I actually appreciate. I start at 7 a.m. every weekday and finish at 4 p.m., with some flexibility if I need to leave a little early or stay late for a deadline. The company has a pretty standard structure, which helps me plan my week around family time, personal goals, and even my photography. That said, there are times when things get a bit unpredictable—like when we're launching a new project or preparing for a big client presentation. In those cases, I might have to stay late or come in on a weekend, but those instances are rare. I think the predictability of my schedule has been one of the things that helped me build a stable life. It gives me the freedom to know that I can show up for my family, take care of my health, and still have time to grow professionally. I've learned that consistency is key for me, and having a reliable schedule makes it easier to balance everything without feeling overwhelmed.

Interviewer: Overall, how do you feel about your financial situation?

Marcus Cortez: Overall, I feel pretty content with my financial situation, even if it's not where I want to be just yet. I know I'm not rolling in money, but I've managed to build a stable life for myself without going into debt or sacrificing my health and well-being. I used to worry that I'd never be able to break free from the cycle my parents were in, but now I see that I've created something better for myself. I'm not rich, but I'm not struggling either, and that gives me a sense of security. I think the most important thing is that I'm in control of my finances, and I'm making choices that align with my long-term goals. I'm not chasing wealth for the sake of it—I'm chasing stability, and I believe that's something worth working toward. I know there's still a lot I want to achieve, but I'm proud of the progress I've made so far, and I'm confident that with time and consistency, I can keep moving in the right direction.

Going through the recent interview topics from questions 36 to 40 made me reflect on how much my financial stability and work-life balance have shaped my sense of security and well-being. Talking about my fluctuating bills reminded me of how important it is to be prepared for unexpected expenses, and how small adjustments—like setting aside money for emergencies or being mindful of my spending—can make a big difference in the long run. It also made me think about how my job as a business analyst provides me with a steady income and benefits, which I didn't take for granted until I considered what life would be like without that stability. Discussing my work schedule and how predictable it is helped me realize how much that consistency has allowed me to build a life that feels balanced and manageable. I used to think that working long hours or having an unpredictable schedule was a sign of dedication, but now I see that it's about being productive and efficient, not just working more. Interviewer: Did your mom/dad work for pay for at least a year while you were growing up?

Marcus Cortez: Yes, both my mom and dad worked for pay while I was growing up, though their situations were different. My dad worked at a factory for most of my childhood, and while it wasn't a high-paying job, he always did his best to provide for our family. He worked long hours, sometimes coming home exhausted, but he never complained. He always told me that if he could give me a better life than he had, he would. My mom, on the other hand, didn't work outside the home for most of my early years. She stayed home with us, which I think was more out of necessity than choice. Back then, it was common for women to stay home, especially in our community, but I know she wanted more for herself. She eventually started taking on part-time jobs, like cleaning or helping out at a local store, to help support the family. It wasn't easy for either of them, but they both made sacrifices so I could have more opportunities than they did. Looking back, I realize how much they gave up for me, and it's something I carry with me every day. It's why I've always believed in education and hard work—it's the only way to break the cycle and create a better future, not just for myself, but for the people I love.

Interviewer: What was their job? What kind of work did they do? What were their most important activities or duties?

Marcus Cortez: My dad worked as a maintenance technician at a local factory, which meant he was responsible for keeping the machinery running smoothly. His days were long and physically demanding—he'd start early in the morning, often before sunrise, and work through the day fixing equipment, replacing parts, and making sure everything was in order. He didn't have much formal training, but he was smart, resourceful, and had a real knack for figuring things out on the spot. He always told me that if you had the right attitude and were willing to work hard, you could make it in this world. My mom, on the other hand, didn't have a traditional job for most of my childhood. She stayed home with us, which I think was more out of necessity than choice. Back then, it was common for women in our community to take on that role, but I know she wanted more for herself. Eventually, she started taking on part-time jobs—cleaning homes, helping out at a local store, even babysitting for neighbors. It wasn't easy for her, and I remember seeing her struggle with the balance between taking care of our family and trying to build a life for herself. Looking back, I realize how much they both gave up for me, and it's something I carry with me every day. It's why I've always believed in education and hard work—it's the only way to break the cycle and create a better future, not just for myself, but for the people I love.

Interviewer: What kind of place did they work for? What kind of business was them? What did they make or do?

Marcus Cortez: My dad worked for a local manufacturing plant that produced automotive parts. It was one of those old-school factories with big machines and a lot of noise. He was responsible for maintaining the equipment, troubleshooting issues, and making sure everything ran smoothly. It wasn't the kind of job that required a college degree, but it was physically demanding and required a lot of attention to detail. He always said that if you treated the machines with respect, they would treat you back. As for my mom, when she did take on part-time jobs, she worked for a few different people—mostly cleaning homes or helping out at small businesses. She never had a lot of money, but she was always willing to do whatever it took to help our family. Looking back, I realize how much they both sacrificed for me, and it's something I carry with me every day. It's why I've always believed in education and hard work—it's the only way to break the cycle and create a better future, not just for myself, but for the people I love.

Interviewer: We all have hopes about what our future will look like. Imagine yourself a few years from now. Maybe you want your life to be the same in some ways as it is now. Maybe you want it to be different in some ways. What do you hope for?

Marcus Cortez: A few years from now, I hope I'm still in San Francisco, maybe in a slightly better apartment, but more importantly, I hope I'm in a place where I feel fulfilled—not just financially, but personally. I want to have a little more stability in my life, maybe even a small emergency fund that's more than just a few hundred dollars. I also hope I'm still working in business analysis, but perhaps in a role that gives me more responsibility or the chance to mentor someone else, just like the people who helped me along the way. I want to be someone who can look back and say I made the right choices, not just for myself, but for the people I care about. I also hope I'm still taking photos, that I've found a way to turn that passion into something more meaningful, even if it's just a small side project. And if I ever do have a partner or children, I want to be the kind of person who can provide for them without sacrificing who I am. I don't need to be rich or famous—I just want to be content, knowing I've built a life that's stable, responsible, and full of purpose.

Interviewer: What do you value the most in your life?

Marcus Cortez: What I value the most in my life is the sense of stability I've built for myself, along with the relationships that have helped me get here. I've always believed that without a strong foundation—whether it's financial, emotional, or familial—everything else in life feels uncertain. My parents taught me that hard work and education are the keys to breaking cycles, and I carry that lesson with me every day. I also value the small moments that bring me joy, like the quiet mornings on my balcony, the sound of my camera shutter clicking, or even the simple act of cooking a meal at home. These things remind me that life isn't just about achieving goals—it's about finding meaning in the everyday. I value being responsible, not just for myself, but for the people I care about, and I hope that one day, I can be that kind of support for someone else, just like the people who helped me along the way.
